definitions.definition: the process of changing or improving the condition of something or the way it works; the process of putting something back into the state it was in before

examples.text: the reconstruction of the educational system
The country faces a huge task of national reconstruction following the war.
companies bidding for post-war reconstruction contracts

definitions.definition: the activity of building again something that has been damaged or destroyed

examples.text: the reconstruction of the sea walls
The bombed city is now undergoing extensive reconstruction.

definitions.definition: a copy of something that no longer exists

examples.text: The doorway is a nineteenth-century reconstruction of Norman work.
a historical reconstruction based on contemporary documents
a life-size reconstruction of a Viking longboat
a dramatic reconstruction of school life in the 1940s

definitions.definition: an act of acting out events that are known to have happened, in order to try and get more information or better understanding about what happened, especially a crime

examples.text: Last night police staged a reconstruction of the incident.
The police have staged a reconstruction of the events leading up to the murder.

definitions.definition: (in the US) the period after the Civil War when the southern states returned to the US and laws were passed that gave rights to African Americans
